I moved the dir of tracker to the removable drive.

It stopped crashing for some reason. If the drive is not connected I get a load of errors from gnome-music in the console and it refuses to play anything but does not crash anymore.

```
Output of example song:
LANG=en_US.UTF-8 tracker info /media/user/WD4TB/backup-wd2tb-110618/Data/Musik/Ane_Brun/A\ Temporary\ Dive/01\ -\ Track\ 1.ogg

Results:

I tried a couple of songs and they all have empty results.

```

Currently indexed: 13678 files, 1409 folders

All data miners are idle, indexing complete

Although there are >21.000 music files in the music directory.

16:54:37 DEBUG	PlayerPlaylist._on_discovered(<PlayerPlayList>, <GstPbutils.Discoverer object at 0x7fc27a371288 (GstDiscoverer at 0x56228649f540)>, <GstPbutils.DiscovererInfo object at 0x7fc273bfc4c8 (GstDiscovererInfo at 0x5622891bcda0)>, GLib.Error('Resource not found.', 'gst-resource-error-quark', 3))[player.py:254]

events.target_title: Crash when clicking on items in playlist while the indexed music is not accessible

note.body:
It plays fine when the drive is plugged in and mounted before start. 

It just locked up in the UI while playing and the debug-message-flow stopped when I tested starting it and plugging the drive in while loading album-art or whatever it does on startup. 
When the song ended it did not play or do anything else nor respondo to pressing the corner to quit. "Loading" with a stuck blue round symbol. Killed it from the terminal.

Following this the next three times I started gnome-music it did not play and crashed when clicking on any track. 

```
17:11:32 WARNING	Error: g-io-error-quark, Operation not supported
17:11:32 WARNING	Error: g-io-error-quark, Operation not supported
17:11:33 WARNING	Error: g-io-error-quark, Operation not supported
17:11:33 WARNING	Error: g-io-error-quark, Operation not supported
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/lib/python3.7/site-packages/gnomemusic/player.py", line 258, in _on_discovered
    index = self._validation_indexes[url].pop(0)
IndexError: pop from empty list
```
This was the error every time.

4th time it plays and acts normally. Nothing changed in between.

How do I trigger a reset and rescan of the collection? (wondering if this would change anything)

events.target_title: stripped exif data if Camera make is "PENTAX"

note.body: Also occurs with JPEGs from a Pentax Optio I-10 P&S with Make string = "PENTAX". Fixed by setting Make to "Pentax" or seemingly any string except "PENTAX" (with gimp 2.10.4 on Windows 7 and 2.10.5 on Mint 18.03). Does not seem to be linked with an all-uppercase name: when I change the Make string to "GARBAG" (with Exiftool), EXIF info is saved.

events.target_title: stripped exif data if Camera make is "PENTAX"

note.body: I tried almost the same, with same result: I took a CR2 file (from EOS 1DX) which was on a HDD, processed it with UFRaw then Gimp 2.8 to a JPEG, changed the "Canon" string to "PENTAX" with Exiftool and still got EXIF in the output with Gimp 2.10. There may be something odd/different in the Pentax EXIF.

events.target_title: stripped exif data if Camera make is "PENTAX"

note.body: Another interesting test: I downloaded a K100D .PEF raw file with "PENTAX Corporation" make string, processed it to JPEG through UFRaw-Gimp 2.8. The JPEG kept its EXIF after editing in Gimp 2.10. This could confirm the hypothesis of something "different" in the JPEG processing of the Pentax. I also processed the same .PEF with nUFRaw-Gimp 2.10, and the EXIF was still in the JPEG export.

events.target_title: stripped exif data if Camera make is "PENTAX"

note.body:
Due to the Japanese-English translation, I'm not sure of the meaning of the sentence "Exif data was not output in 4 of these test cases 4." Do you mean that Exif data were in the output, except in case 4? This would confirm my own tests. Else, this would mean that the case is even more complicated than we thought.

All the Pentax files I tried had the string "PENTAX Corporation" (or "PENTAX" for the JPEG-only files from an Optio I-10), and, after my tests, I concluded that the issue was in the JPEG output from Pentax cameras, and is not only connected with all-capitals names and the string "PENTAX" or "PENTAX Corporation". One could compare the outputs of "exiftool foo.jpg".

My Optio I-10 exif data could be of some use, too, because Gimp 2.10 always strips their EXIF and the exiftool output is rather short and simple; so I attach the exiftool output from an out-of-the box picture.

[IMGP4116.TXT](/uploads/21325f99cb95e9f3470800c9d31218fc/IMGP4116.TXT)

I checked that the output file from Gimp 2.10 had no EXIF.

events.target_title: stripped exif data if Camera make is "PENTAX"

note.body:
I did another experiment: as files are somehow "patched" when you change the "PENTAX (Corporation)" string with exiftool, I edited a file from my Optio I-10 with an hex edidor, so that the only difference between old and new file was PENTAX/Pentax (50 45 4E 54 41 58 —> 50 65 6E 74 61 78).

And the output from Gimp 2.10 kept the exif!

So the issue has also something to do with PENTAX written in uppercase.

Rather puzzling, isn't it…

events.target_title: stripped exif data if Camera make is "PENTAX"

note.body:
My English is not such good either…

At least a question remains without answer: why is the issue **fixed** by changing "PENTAX" to "Pentax", but not **caused** by writing "PENTAX" instead of another camera's brand, as if the PENTAX name **plus** some particular structure of the Pentax EXIF (which is not reproduced when developing a PEF file with RawTherpee, DarkTable or UFRaw) were involved together?

There is no issue with other brands written in capitals like "LEICA CAMERA AG". I could not find a six-letter camera brand which I could change to "PENTAX" without touching other bytes. Other tries don't reproduce the bug.

Maybe we should look at the sources of gexiv2? But I'm not good enough in C to find an error there, except by chance, and the error could be from an include file like jpgimage.hpp which is not in the sources of gexiv2.

events.target_title: stripped exif data if Camera make is "PENTAX"

note.body:
As things seemed to be the same for "PENTAX Corporation" and "PENTAX", I did several tries with JPEGs from several brands with "PENTAX" only with the same negative result as for Canon. I can try with "PENTAX Corporation".

(I was reading gexiv2-metadata.cpp and some other files in gexiv2, and I thought that many things were able to raise an error and cause the exif not to be written…)

note.body:
> After all the structure of metadata seems to be related to bug

I performed other tests with a PENTAX K-30 SOOC jpeg (Make: "PENTAX", Exif Byte Order: Big-endian), **only** modifying "PENTAX" with an hexadecimal editor:

No exif on Gimp 2010 jpeg export with Make="PENTAX". I get the exif when I change Make to "PENPAX".

Decidedly, everything goes as if the code told:

IF ((Exif.image.Make='PENTAX') OR (Exif.image.Make='PENTAX Corporation')) AND (some other condition in the exif) THEN strip exif ;)

(Maybe: if the first six characters are 'PENTAX').

events.target_title: During file saving, GIMP crashes. Result: file now 0 bytes. What happened and how to get it back?
During file saving, GIMP crashes. Result: file now 0 bytes. What happened and how to get it back?

note.body:
Nothing? No reason for the official GIMP-issues site to check the kind of bug that other software hasn't had since the early 90s?

Because of the bug, the user must now make special back-ups outside GIMP, and as often as other programs do it automatically and internally, because every time GIMP starts to save a file, it might instead make it disappear permanently. 
It doesn't matter if the real problem is the user's computer or operating system: it's GIMP that isn't able to manage its own open file when whatever other problem might be happening. That means that GIMP is no longer a realiable program. 

What Photoshop alternatives are there besides GIMP?

note.body:

events.target_title: seahorse 3.20.0 consumes all RAM and CPU

note.body: Found out this is caused by Konstantin Ryabitsev's key: https://pgp.surfnet.nl/pks/lookup?op=vindex&fingerprint=on&search=0xE63EDCA9329DD07E which is fairly large. I also have auto-key-retrieve and auto-key-locate wkd,dane,local in my gnupg configuration.

events.target_title: gsd-locate-pointer can grab mouse and never release it

note.body: I unfortunately don't remember, and I solved this issue by disabling the locate pointer feature.  I will try to re-enable it, and see if I can reproduce the issue.  IIRC, when it was happening, it only happened about once a week, so it would have to be something kind of rare.  One thing to note is that the computer is a convertible laptop (I assume that since the touchscreen is a separate pointer, it won't interfere, but maybe bad things happen when you touch the screen while the pointer is locked?).  The other strange thing about the laptop is that when you put it into tablet mode, the keyboard and touchpad simply stop responding.

events.target_title: gsd-locate-pointer can grab mouse and never release it

note.body: huh, it looks like when I filed this ticket, I used a different account.  That's exciting.

events.target_title: Delay on opening the overview

note.body:
Update: if only a few applications are opened and the shell is cleanly restarted then opening the overview is instant. 
Should I change the nice level of gnome-shell?

I think gnome wants to render all windows before the opening of the overview, it should be done progressively, there is no matter if some app has black screen(or something lighter than a thumbnail) but it should be instant.

events.target_title: Opening any file causes a crash in cairo_surface_create_similar on OSX 10.14

note.body:
Hi Alex,

I move the folder to my desktop but when I open gimp it still crash when I try to make a new file.

jeroen

events.target_title: Opening any file causes a crash in cairo_surface_create_similar on OSX 10.14

note.body: Gimp crashed when I choose new in the file menu (⌘ N), but also when I drag a file into the gimp window, tried this with a png and jpg format. But gimp also crashes when I open a image from the file menu (⌘ O)

events.target_title: Opening any file causes a crash in cairo_surface_create_similar on OSX 10.14

note.body: I install the cli debug package but what do you mean by the updated trace, you mean the output when starting gimp with the verbose mode, gimp --verbose?

events.target_title: Why is there no "delete permanently"?

note.body:
Thanks for the instant reply @aklapper .

Thanks for asking. It apparently forces me to re-think vocabulary and workflows. :)

Hm, probably the difference between Evolution and Thunderbird is in how the terminology is used here.

In Thunderbird, "delete" can be configured to "move email to [a real] trash folder", which I find very useful (I have to additionally hit "shift" to actually delete). In this configuration, "delete permanently" means "don't move the message to the trash folder but mark it `\Deleted`".

Can Evolution be configured to use a real trash folder? I guess only then a "delete permanently" would make sense, hu?

[off]
BTW, my background is that I'd love to move from Thunderbird (where the terrible performance drives me nuts) to Evolution and promote it among all my friends and all that but for this to happen, I need to find solutions to fix or work around a few personal show stoppers. :)
[/off]

events.target_title: Could we not trigger keyboard shortcuts when the key (combination) is actually an input to a text field?
Why is there no "delete permanently"?

note.body:
Awesome, thanks.

Then, if users configure a real trash folder, would make "delete permanently" (i.e., do not move to trash folder but mark `\Deleted`) sense?

events.target_title: Could we not trigger keyboard shortcuts when the key (combination) is actually an input to a text field?

note.body:
Hm, sad, but thanks for the reply.

A) Is there a list for "possible future features" or similar?
B) Could this functionality implemented as plugin?

Cheers.

events.target_title: Could we not trigger keyboard shortcuts when the key (combination) is actually an input to a text field?

note.body:
Appreciate your time and replies.

A) Well this feature request is posted under https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/evolution/issues/ isn't it? Are possible future features / feature request kept as closed issues labeled "out of scope"? ;) Now without the irony: I did not open this issue and expected that maintainers implement this feature, the intention was to keep the idea somewhere publicly.

I am well aware of the FLOSS mechanism of forking, implementing and merging. I am not into GTK and desktop application development at all, but would this feature have at least a chance to get merged if someone would implement it?

B) Yes, I am aware; I just don't know if this functionality could be achieved with a plugin. But if you don't know as well, experimenting would probably be the only way to find out.

events.target_title: Why is there no "delete permanently"?

note.body:
Thanks a lot for the explanations, @mcrha.

An alternative to your a)..d) would be to have a separate "hidden" folder where emails which are to be deleted permanently get moved to, marked for deletion and expunged. But it is likewise hackish and not necessarily better.
For me, the "delete permanently" only makes sense if there is a real trash folder, so "delete permanently" just means "mark for deletion and expunge". If we then accidentally expunge emails which have been marked for deletion on other devices, that is something that could happen today as well "by IMAP design", isn't it?

Anyway, no need to discuss this further, I guess.
Thanks for taking this suggestion serious, the discussion and the pointers.

events.target_title: [Wayland] Alt Tab broken since a recent commit

note.body:
I see this issue too. For me, launching gedit shortly after booting and logging in causes ALT-TAB to not work until clicking in any open window. I say shortly after, because the problem went away for me a few times, but I haven’t figured out a way to reproduce that yet.

Also, gnome-terminal launches without focus if launched while focus is on certain applications, such as Firefox, thunderbird and qt-creator. There may be others, but those are the ones I have found. ALT-TAB works in this scenario.

I agree that the commit is correct and it does fix X11 session. But reverting it does make the issue go away in Wayland, with one caveat. With the commit reverted, Firefox doesn’t have focus when launched. 

I should note that I am launching all applications from Activities search bar and also am running arch Linux. I tried with the latest commit [1b5e91e4](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-shell/commit/1b5e91e4b3f6f6f035c768865d220b36f945c616) of gnome-shell but that made no difference.

events.target_title: Black stripe under the view when full screen

note.body:
Full-screen issue seems to be how video was placed into full-screen. By double clicking the running video, pressing 'F11' key, pressing 'F' key, or pressing 'F5' key; full-screen is either cut at the bottom and top with an empty area at the bottom or the video stays at the same resolution when the window player started.

Work around seems to be using the full-screen button on the top-right of the header / title bar. Once the full-screen is engaged in that manor, all other forms of entering and exit full-screen start to work properly sometimes.

Issue also arises where exiting full-screen reduces the resolution to the initial window player mode but the screen actual rectangle is equal to the full-screen size shifted by the initial window placement.

events.target_title: Random high CPU usage

note.body:
This occurs with Wayland.

From `journald`:
```
org.gnome.Shell.desktop[2610]: Key repeat discarded, Wayland compositor doesn't seem to be processing events fast enough!
```

Only way to stop this is by killing the shell remotely or restart using the power button.

I also notice the only way to prevent this is to logout and back in once the shell starts to run slow.

events.target_title: Timeline Control not accepting mouse clicks on Wayland with AMD graphics card

note.body:
The actual issue is with Cutter and the handling of 8bit and 10bit color depth. https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/clutter/merge_requests/10.

Running Totem with `env allow_rgb10_configs=false totem` allows for the control to work properly.

events.target_title: workspace.get_neighbor() no longer works with LEFT and RIGHT directions

note.body:
The problem seems to be that `meta_workspace_manager_override_workspace_layout()` only allows the layout to be set once. Any further calls fail silently. Extensions are thus unable to change the layout from the single column set by the Shell itself and `meta_workspace_get_neighbor()` respects this layout, whatever the extension may think.

The attached patch fixes things.

[0001-Allow-workspace-layout-to-be-overridden.patch](/uploads/73ac4a8bafffb637e3f3f6510fc7027e/0001-Allow-workspace-layout-to-be-overridden.patch)

Not sure it's the same issue but I'll try to reproduce.

Actually IIRC the issue I have (maybe not only using MATE) is that when using opening the Screen Reader Preferences GUI the X keyboard map is changed as if setxkbmap had been used.

For the moment I just made a wrapper script (ugly workaround, yes):

didier[~/.aide-memoire]$ cat /usr/bin/orca

setxkbmap
didier[~/.aide-memoire]$
```

I will look at that again in the coming days (busy with speech-dispatcher at the moment).

Didier

events.target_title: After closing the orca setttings dialog in ubuntu MATE the keyboard layout is changed to the english layout

note.body:
I just tried.  
  
Context:  
orca 3.29.4 pre  
mate 1.18.1  
xorg-server 1.18.3  
 
Orca is started at the user level by ~/.config/autostart/startorca.desktop:
[Desktop Entry]
Type=Application
Version=1.0
Name=orca
Exec=/usr/bin/orca
Hidden=false

The X keyboard layout is set in /etc/X11/xorg.conf.d/10-keymap.conf:  
Section "InputClass"  
	Identifier		"Keyboard-all"  
	MatchIsKeyboard		"yes"  
	MatchDevicePath 	"/dev/input/event*"  
	Driver			"evdev"  
	Option			"XkbLayout" "fr"  
	Option			"XkbVariant" ""  
	Option			"XkbOptions" ""  
EndSection  

I typed:  
xkbcomp $DISPLAY -  > dump.xkb.before  
then Orca+space  
then just clicked  Apply then OK  
then typed:  
xkbcomp $DISPLAY -  > dump.xkb.after  
then:  
diff -u dump.xkb.before dump.xkb.after > dump.xkb.diff  
I attach the file dump.xkb.diff  
So, the keyboard layout has changed.  
That's all I know.  
[dump.xkb.diff](/uploads/3a9c68855aafa39b6def4a3eb2a08cdd/dump.xkb.diff)

events.target_title: After closing the orca setttings dialog in ubuntu MATE the keyboard layout is changed to the english layout

note.body:
Addendum to my previous message: this is not MATE specific as I observed the same behavior in other graphical environments, namely: LXDE, blackbox, fluxbox, kde4, xfce.

Only wmaker is immune of all that I have tried.

events.target_title: After closing the orca setttings dialog in ubuntu MATE the keyboard layout is changed to the english layout

note.body:
Here this issue happens only if setxkbmap has not been run before starting orca, so just executing /usr/bin/setxkbmap before starting the window manager solve this issue.

For instance:
```
bash-4.3$ tail .xinitrc 
if [ -x /usr/bin/ck-launch-session ]; then
	LAUNCH="ck-launch-session"
else
	LAUNCH=""
fi
if [ -x /usr/bin/dbus-launch ]; then
	LAUNCH="$LAUNCH dbus-launch"
fi
/usr/bin/setxkbmap
exec $LAUNCH /usr/bin/mate-session
```

events.target_title: How should nested tags be written to JPEG files?
How should nested tags be written to JPEG files?

note.body:
The output from `exiv2 -pa` on the original file shows several properties with the value `Subjects/Animals/Sheep`. These are:

```
Exif.Image.XPKeywords                Subjects/Animals/Sheep
Xmp.dc.subject                       Subjects/Animals/Sheep
Xmp.MicrosoftPhoto.LastKeywordXMP    Subjects/Animals/Sheep
```

After removing the tag `Subjects-Animals-Sheep` in Shotwell, the exif data changes, with the following properties now present:

```
Exif.Image.XPKeywords                Subjects/Animals/Sheep
Iptc.Application2.Keywords           Subjects
Iptc.Application2.Keywords           Animals
Iptc.Application2.Keywords           Sheep
Xmp.MicrosoftPhoto.LastKeywordXMP    Subjects, Subjects/Animals, Subjects/Animals/Sheep
Xmp.xmp.Label                        Subjects
Xmp.dc.subject                       Animals, Sheep, Subjects
Xmp.digiKam.TagsList                 Subjects, Subjects/Animals, Subjects/Animals/Sheep
```

The info that Nautilus displays when inspecting the image properties must be `Xmp.dc.subject`, which Shotwell is rewriting from `Subjects/Animals/Sheep` to `Subjects, Animals, Sheep`.

All this is very confusing. Why is Shotwell interpreting the tag as `Subjects-Animals-Sheep` in the first place? If it can read the original nested tags correctly, why rewrite them as separate values on change?

events.target_title: How should nested tags be written to JPEG files?

Thanks for the clarification. Is this behaviour intentional, or is it a bug?

I'm guessing it should be safe to delete the hyphen-separated tags.

system reliably frozen on encrypted partition unlock prompt
system reliably frozen on encrypted partition unlock prompt
system reliably frozen on encrypted partition unlock prompt

note.body:
You're right. At that response handler we don't know if the entered password is correct. Thus, if we want to re-use the dialog, we cannot explicitly close it there.

I have done some more debugging on this. The `ShellMountOperation` instance and the misbehaving password dialog will be created by the `_checkAndMountVolume` method of the `AutomountManager` class. No matter if the Cancel button or the Unlock button is clicked on the password dialog, the `AutomountManager._closeOperation` method will always be called as expected. But inside this method the `volume._operation.close()` line will never be called, as the `volume._operation` property is always undefined at this place.

At the end of the `AutomountManager._mountVolume` method, this property is always there, whereas at the beginning of the `_onVolumeMounted` the `volume._operation` property is always undefined. Thus, this property must be somehow removed from the object by the `volume.mount(...)` method in the background.

events.target_title: Promote ethical, privacy-friendly mail providers

note.body:
The best "ethical, privacy friendly" email provider is your own.  Basic smtp/imap is plug and play in almost any distro.  The complication comes when you add authentication (DKIM,SPF) and spam filtering.  

Having a supported suite (smtp,imap,auth,spam) would be a big encouragement to just run your own email.  Registering a domain is ~$10/yr and a VPS sufficient for personal email is ~$30/yr, so there is no need for people to have a server in their home.  

There *are* small email appliances that could be supported (although who knows what the proprietary appliances report to HQ).  OpenWRT supports email, although I've not yet tried it.

A first small step for the timid is just to register your own domain for email, and pay gmail (or whatever) to host your email with your own domain.  Then you can easily switch providers (including providing your own) at will.

events.target_title: Promote ethical, privacy-friendly mail providers

note.body:
My personal suite is currently sendmail,dovecot,pymilter(pyspf,pydkim),pymilter(pydspam).

However, sendmail is not noob friendly and the pymilter config is a total mess of quick hacks.  Opensmtpd is really simple, but you would then need MDA based agents for auth and spam.

events.target_title: Issues with systemLanguage condition

note.body:
There are several levels of fixes that can be done, and I would do them as a progression.

The first step is to distinguish locale and langtag. SVG does not care about locale; SVG offers no facility for formatting dates, numbers, or currency. It only cares about langtags, and only then for the systemLanguage attribute.

1. Fix the locale string (e.g., "en_US") and langtag (e.g., "en-US") confusion. Langtags never have an underscore.
master/rsvg_internals/src/cond.rs
line 138: "en_US" to "en-US"
line 156: "en_US" to "en-US"

2. Fix the backward prefix match
lines 79-81 get the case-insensitive equal test correct ("en-US" = "en-us").
lines 83-85 are backward and too complicated. The second prong should return true iff
```
    l.length < sl.length AND
    l.eq_ignore_ascii_case(&sl[..(l.length)]) AND
    sl[l.length] == '-'
```
The test cases should have different results
line 167: should be false
I would add other tests:
* "en-GB" against `&system_languages`; result should be false (user demands British English; prefix match fails).
* "en" against `&system_languages`; result should be true (user wants any variety of English; prefix match succeeds).

You then have minimal conformance. Currently, Wikipedia would be happy if you stopped here.

3. Multiple language preferences for a user.
Instead of a single language preference, allow several.
Chrome recently did this change.
Instead of a single `l`, test against an array of preferred langtags.

"messages" provides such a preference list, but there's risk of confusion here. librsvg should have an argument to specify the preference list in langtags rather than locale strings. If the argument is not given, then librsvg can infer the preference list from "messages" (or some other source). Consider an image server that received an HTTP request with Accept-Languages; do not force that server to convert the langtags to locale strings in order to synthesize an LC_MESSAGES environment variable.

4. SMIL allowReorder.
AFAIK, only Firefox does allowReorder processing. That processing only affects the `switch` element.
NB: SVG does not have an `allowReorder` attribute, so none of your test cases should have that attribute and the processing should not be conditioned on that attribute.
Firefox computes a score for a systemLanguage match. If l_i is the i-th preferred langtag, then the score is 2 * l_i if the langtag is an exact match and 2 * l_i + 1 if the langtag is a prefix match; no match gets a score of infinity (e.g., 2 * l.length). Low score wins.

events.target_title: Issues with systemLanguage condition

note.body:
Federico,

I don't know Rust, so I cannot follow all of what is going on it the code.

From a character count aspect, it looks too complex. The comparison should be simple.

I think it is a mistake to use locales in cond.rs. The SVG standard is not about locales but rather langtags. When librsvg starts up, it should build its preferred langtag and save it as a global langtagUserPref (or an array alangtagUserPrefs). Then you're done with locales. Down the road, you won't have to convert a user langtag preference list that came from somewhere else (such as an API argument) to locales to use this code.

Both Chrome and Firefox use string comparisons rather than locale libraries.

I do not know what the folding is doing. I'm expecting it to iterate the systemLanguage tags until there is a match, but I'm not sure.

I'm troubled by the .unwrap().0. IIRC from last night, an unwrap() removed private extensions ("-x-*") from a langtag, but such private extensions should not be removed. If the user states a preference of en-US-x-Milwaukee, then he does not want just en-US. (Unwrap may also be something benign that is being done to the fold accumulation. As I said, I do not know Rust.)

IIRC, SVG seeks to use BCP-47 basic matching. I'm guessing that's what locale_accepts_language_tag(locale, &language_tag) purports to do, but here again we cannot be sure. Locales can include character sets and sort orders. There may be equivalence mechanisms that lead to unexpected results. If the locale is Mandarin with simplified Chinese script, is the locale going to match "zh-cmn-Hans" or "cmn-Hans" or both? Will it match "zh-Hans"?

I'd use string matching rather than a locale library. It may mean there's more work computing the language preference list, but with a given preference list, there is no doubt the matching algorithm follows BCP-47.

There should never be an invalid langtag parse error. Although SVG expects documents to use IETF langtags, it does not prohibit noncompliant tags. For example, "ru-0" and "en-Shorthand" are not legal IETF langtags, but an SVG user agent should not complain about them.

events.target_title: Wrong mapping for Wacom Pad buttons
Better support for ecryptfs
Rename the baobab binary to gnome-disk-usage-analyzer

note.body:
@agarnier the source of this inconsistency is that some gnome applications were renamed to a different naming scheme so that their names indicate their functionality (See [Arch wiki on GNOME Legacy names](https://wiki.archlinux.org/index.php/GNOME#Legacy_names)). But the application names stayed the same. Presumably so that existing scripts don't fail. Same thing for GNOME Files whose binary is still called nautilus.

IMHO the best way to solve this is to include symlinks with these apps.

note.body:
>  your project is almost certainly compiling with GCC

Yes, in fact ccache + GCC.

> while the diagnostics engine is powered by libclang.

I figured that because I dug into the code a bit. But I didn't think that this was the issue because the same code inside the source file (in `main.cpp`) does not trigger a warning.

> If you run Builder with `-vvvv`, I think you can see the `$CFLAGS`

Are you sure about that? I couldn't make it out in all of the debug messages.
Even using `gnome-builder -vvvv | grep "\-std\|CFLAGS"` and rewriting some code didn't reveal anything.

Anyway I'm sorry I didn't append the logs in my original post. Just fixed that.

> Another option to test, is to use CC=clang when compiling with meson to see what happens.
```
$ env CC=clang CXX=clang++ meson builddir-clang
The Meson build system
Version: 0.49.2
Source dir: /home/cedric/Nextcloud/Code/cpp17
Build dir: /home/cedric/Nextcloud/Code/cpp17/builddir-clang

Build machine cpu family: x86_64

$ env CC=clang CXX=clang++ ninja -v
[1/2] clang++ -Icpp17@exe -I. -I.. -Xclang -fcolor-diagnostics -pipe -D_FILE_OFFSET_BITS=64 -Wall -Winvalid-pch -Wnon-virtual-dtor -std=c++17 -g  -MD -MQ 'cpp17@exe/main.cpp.o' -MF 'cpp17@exe/main.cpp.o.d' -o 'cpp17@exe/main.cpp.o' -c ../main.cpp
[2/2] clang++  -o cpp17 'cpp17@exe/main.cpp.o' -Wl,--no-undefined -Wl,--as-needed

The project compiles without any warnings or errors using the same meson build file and clang. And as you can see `-std=c++17` is correctly passed to clang. So there's nothing wrong with the build file.

events.target_title: pam_gnome_keyring.so starts a new gnome-keyring-daemon every login
pam_gnome_keyring.so starts a new gnome-keyring-daemon every login

note.body:
I did some further debugging. This appears to be related to the patch 2ca51a0aef5b ("daemon: Stop exporting the $GNOME_KEYRING_CONTROL env variable", 2014-03-06).

Basically, the XDG_RUNTIME_DIR isn't set at the time that pam is loading, so we simply report no daemon loaded, even though it actually is.

I'm not sure this is strictly a bug in the pam_gnome_keyring.so...

events.target_title: pam_gnome_keyring.so starts a new gnome-keyring-daemon every login

note.body: Specifically, I think this is somehow caused because the pam configuration is not loading XDG_RUNTIME_DIR properly before loading the pam_gnome_keyring.so...

note.body:
@fmuellner I am running Debian (testing), and have:

```
$ dpkg -l | grep shell | grep gnome
ii  chrome-gnome-shell                      9-1                                     all          GNOME Shell extensions integration for web browsers
ii  gnome-shell                             3.30.0-2                                amd64        graphical shell for the GNOME desktop
ii  gnome-shell-common                      3.30.0-2                                all          common files for the GNOME graphical shell
ii  gnome-shell-extensions                  3.30.0-1                                all          Extensions to extend functionality of GNOME Shell
```

What would you suggest here?

I have the same error as the orignial reporter. VPN connection works - I get prompted for the passphrase. Suspending and resuming and WiFi re-establishes itself correctly. Unfortunately the VPN does not (and manually attempting to connect doesn't work either).

All I see is:

```
Oct 05 08:15:50 radha NetworkManager[1553]: <info>  [1538720150.5340] audit: op="connection-activate" uuid="2341c0a5-c5b4-4f95-8eaa-26cdd8153391" name="HERE" pid=5466 uid=1000 result="success"
Oct 05 08:15:50 radha NetworkManager[1553]: <info>  [1538720150.5475] vpn-connection[0x55a33b49e4e0,2341c0a5-c5b4-4f95-8eaa-26cdd8153391,"HERE",0]: Started the VPN service, PID 6657
Oct 05 08:15:50 radha NetworkManager[1553]: <info>  [1538720150.5655] vpn-connection[0x55a33b49e4e0,2341c0a5-c5b4-4f95-8eaa-26cdd8153391,"HERE",0]: Saw the service appear; activating connection
Oct 05 08:15:50 radha NetworkManager[1553]: <error> [1538720150.5732] vpn-connection[0x55a33b49e4e0,2341c0a5-c5b4-4f95-8eaa-26cdd8153391,"HERE",0]: Failed to request VPN secrets #3: No agents were available for this request.
Oct 05 08:15:50 radha NetworkManager[1553]: <info>  [1538720150.5772] vpn-connection[0x55a33b49e4e0,2341c0a5-c5b4-4f95-8eaa-26cdd8153391,"HERE",0]: VPN service disappeared

```

As noted in https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-shell/issues/136, you can workaround  this without requiring a logout by running the command line: `nmcli connection up <vpn> --ask`

Let me know if there is anything you would like me to do to assist in debugging.

events.target_title: GIMP 2.10.2 becomes really slow from time to time

note.body:
I'm using 2.10.6 on Windows 10 Fall 2018 ... and after some time the performance of GIMP decreases dramatically. Only a restart helps to improve that.

e.g. an 8bit PNG (from screen shot) with about 1000x1000px, duplicating the layer, marking three tiny areas (as in 20x8px), using linear blur filter, works fine, selecting some bigger areas (as in 200x20px), have them outlined with color still works fine ... exporting back to PNG and XCF also is considerable fine.

This works great for two or three pictures (all pictures are quite the same size). But starting with the third or fourth picture the filter causes GIMP to get blocked (similar filter as in the first example now lasts over 30 seconds), so does the outline ... exporting back to PNG takes a deep breath too ... only saving as XCF seems fine.

The filter causes 25% CPU utilization on a 16GB, Intel64 Family 6 Model 94 Stepping 3 notebook.
So there is still enough memory (at least 5GB) and CPU left ... but it gets blocked somewhere.

events.target_title: Mouse acceleration setting hard to find and needs tweaks installed

note.body:
Personally, I don't mind default mouse acceleration profile in Gnome, but this is indeed a serious issue for gamers. When lurking around linux gamers' forums, "weird" mouse acceleration is a recurring problem (especially for people coming straight from Windows, e.g. after last months Valve's Proton release).

At this point I think there are following options, that could be exposed through Gnome Control Center:

* Acceleration profile: Adaptive/Flat
* Acceleration speed (only for Adaptive profile): floating point in the range -1..1

For reference, more documentation about acceleration: https://wayland.freedesktop.org/libinput/doc/latest/pointer-acceleration.html

Is libinput used in Gnome for X server, Wayland and Xwayland, or does it vary?

events.target_title: Broken "Back" button

note.body:
I can reproduce the issue using the following steps:

1.  Open Software
2.  Select any software title that brings you to the details page (where one can download the piece of software and such)
3.  Close the window
4.  Open Software again

After these steps, you'll be in the same page as when you closed the previous window, but now pressing the back button doesn't work, and you get the assertion error as described by @dima. The steps above also produce the issue if one merely goes to one of the software categories.

EDIT: I'd say that the back button should default to putting the user to the main page of Software if the stack is empty. While in my reproducing case it mightn't be exactly what the user expects, it's better than having to reboot IMHO.

events.target_title: [Prefer Plain] Generate plain text from text/html, if not available
Consistent Display of HTML part inside email.
[Prefer Plain] Generate plain text from text/html, if not available

note.body:
Closing this report as not actionable is not a very friendly reply, Mr Klapper, and quite frankly wrong.

Creating a visible yellow pop-under with the target URL in bold and large enough font seems actionable to me.

Creating a stripped version of the HTML part and displaying it instead of the HTML part seems actionable to me, and is what Thunderbird has been doing for ages.

You made no attempt to understand my feedback.  I have tried all four preferences in "Mail Preferences > HTML Messages" and none of them is good enough.

(a) "Show HTML" for obvious reasons.  The goal is to display TEXT.
(b) "Show plain text if present" because in absence of plain text it shows the HTML with the URL hidden behind the beautified HTML link, and with inconspicuous notice to the user, dark grey over light grey in the bottom line.
(c) "Show plain text if present, or HTML source" is the one that come closest to the objective of conspicuous notice to the user about the target URL that they are going to click
(d) "Only ever show plain text" is also not usable, since the user needs to access the content of the HTML and ends up either with a hidden URL in a beautified link in the external viewer, or with the same problem of trying to decypher the HTML source, as in (c).

This is a usability problem.  On your car's dashboard you want to have the speed and fuel gauge closer to your eyes than say the radio tuner or the air conditioning settings.  Similarly, on my email client, I would like to have the target URL visible and noticeable before being led to click on a link that may lead to dangerous resources.

Please re-open and remove that wrong Not Actionable tag.

events.target_title: [Prefer Plain] Generate plain text from text/html, if not available
Consistent Display of HTML part inside email.

note.body:
As I tried to explain to you in Issue #353, all combinations under "Mail Preferences > HTML Messages > Plain Text Mode" do not achieve the desired result.

>  (An application cannot display plain text if there is no plain text to display.)

Plain text can be generated from stripping down the HTML.  The code for that is probably already in Evolution to allow a plain text reply to an HTML mail.  Thunderbird does exactly that:  generates the plain text by stripping down the HTML tags and making sure the content is readable.  It works very well, to a point that I prefer to receive HTML-only mails than multi-part mails with a borked text part as so many entities are sending nowadays.

Last but not least, my comment stand: the behaviour of Evolution is inconsistent in that the HTML document attachment is shown in the top gray area just under the headings for some emails (good) and only as a downloadable attachment in the bottom area for other emails (bad).

I am too new to Evolution and do not understand how you conclude that this report is Not Actionable or Out of Scope.  What I do gather from the speed and quality of the reply is that users are unwanted annoyances.  Thank you for letting me know, I will look for a mail client elsewhere.

events.target_title: Consistent Display of HTML part inside email.
[Prefer Plain] Generate plain text from text/html, if not available

note.body:
Thank you for understanding that this is a feature request.

I have indeed not clearly defined what I mean with "malformed email."  My apology.  In my view, there are a number of degrees to which an email can be malformed.  Some malformations are hard (as in: offending an RFC).  Others are soft: the email message itself may be RFC compliant, but it causes confusion to the recipient.

Some examples:

Apple Mail is broken and includes the attachments in the HTML part.  To my understanding, this is contrary to MIME specifications in RFC2045 and RFC2049  in which multipart emails are flat, not nested (it has been a while since I have read these RFCs, so forgive me if my memory is not so fresh).  My expectation in this kind of situations is for my mail reader to help me work around Apple's broken behavior.

A lot of mass mailers (or their users) do not send a TEXT part; send an empty TEXT part; or send a borken TEXT part (the last borken one I received is my credit card stating in TEXT that the monthly statement for the month of ##MM## ##YY## is ready, while in the HTML part the two obvious placeholders have been replaced by the actual month/year combination).  My expectation in this kind of situations is, again, for my mail reader to help me work around the confusing message and make the best sense out of it.

All of these malformed emails have one common denominator: they confuse the recipient.  Unless the recipient conforms to the sender's expectation, which most of the time are, in my view unreasonable.  Senders expect recipient to trust them blindly, to display HTML (without even thinking that the recipient may have a disability preventing them from accessing the colorfully designed and branded content), to trust, download, and display external content; to trust links without knowing to what URL they lead, etc.  

All bad things for the recipient.  Accessibility-mindful and security-conscious users do not do that.  I personally prefer to read emails as text (or as stripped down HTML) because I read faster when it is all on my background, in my font, my size, my color.  

My expectation to a mail client is that it helps the user sort out the message content from the surrounding confusion.  That it helps the user make an informed decision whether to click a link or open an attachment.  That it allows the user to easily switch between different displays.

Plain Text is the first thing I want to see.  I want as much information in it, so that if possible I do not even need to go to HTML.  But if I chose to go to HTML, I'd like it to be one button in one place, consistent and easy to find, with predictable and reliable help, such as tooltips displaying the URL of the link that I am going to click, and a choice to deliberately display external elements AFTER I have seen the passive HTML skeleton.

I hope I have made myself clear.  If not, I apologize in advance and am happy to expand further.  Thank you for taking the time to read my input.

events.target_title: Consistent Display of HTML part inside email.

note.body:
Thanks for the reply and apology for the delay, I only have so much time to dedicate to this matter.

**TL;DR: is there a PPA (preferable) or snap or other way to install the latest Evolution on 'buntu 18.04LTS?  My flavour is Xubuntu (replacing XFCE is non-negotiable at this stage, even if Gnome is totally awesome); and I am stuck with 18.04 for the long term (and that is even less negotiable).** 

I am using Evolution 3.28.5-0ubuntu0.18.04.1 and there is no `Prefer Plain Text` setting under `Edit > Preferences > Mail Preferences > HTML Messages > Plain Text Mode`

There is a `HTML Mode` setting, which I set to Only ever show plain text.

The image below is what I see, left is a TEXT+HTML message, right is HTML-only message.

The inconsistency I see is the lack of the line under the expandable headers, with the text "HTML document attachment (attachment.html) and the two buttons on its left allowing for the display / open in external tool.

From your screenshot, I deduct that you are using a version newer than 3.28.5 and that the inconsistency is no longer there.  I am obviously behind and apologize for issuing a bug report against an older version.  I need to get on the latest and greatest Evolution before wasting your time.

![compare](/uploads/edf166980a48dd12b8e32c848136a3da/compare.png)

events.target_title: [Prefer Plain] Generate plain text from text/html, if not available

note.body:
>  Trying to address buggy mail clients whom send text/plain parts invalid, incomplete or with a different information than their text/html part is impossible.

I encourage you to test-drive Mozilla Thunderbird.  If Mozilla Thunderbird can, then it is not **impossible**.

>  The conversion from text/html to text/plain can loose information too and should be done carefully

Yes indeed.  Conversion is to be considered with regard to its purpose and not to be expected to be 100% perfect.  If memory serves me well, Evolution currently does some sort of conversion when the purpose of the user is to reply in plain text to a message received in HTML, and while formatting elements like bullet points may get lost (and it would be nicer to see them replaced with asterisks), the conversion works well enough.  Conversion for the purpose of reading is a much less demanding purpose than conversion for the purpose of replying.

For me, the purpose to display a text version (with losses) when reading emails is to get a quick look at the message without allowing all for all of its (slower to load/display/read) payload.  There are many reasons why a recipient is not interested in the full payload that the sender wants to deliver.  Examples include:
* color combinations that a color-blind person may not see;
* font/styling that is more difficult or slower to read;
* graphic images that the recipient finds offending.

I find that in most cases I can ignore the elements that get lost in the translation from HTML to TEXT (as performed by Mozilla Thunderbird) without missing on the gist of the message.  In the other cases, I just press a button and display the HTML.  Then I find that much of what is lost in translation is an unimportant waste of my time.  I understand the idea of branding that banks, telcos, and other companies apply to email notifications that I want to receive from them, but I am interested in the substance of those notifications, not in the branding.  Missing on the HTML coloring/formatting/etc. is not a loss, it is a gain of time/performance.

>  You said the URL is shown in the status bar. I consider that sufficient.

Why do you consider that sufficient?  Have you done some usability testing, observed how users interact with Evolution, tracked their eyes movements?  How much time it takes for them to become aware of the target URL?  If they are becoming aware of it at all?

With all due respect, output in dark grey on light grey at the bottom of the window is not particularly noticeable.  I would prefer notice of what I am going to click without having to move my eyes to a peripheral area of the user interaction.  In my view, the target link is a sufficiently important piece of information to warrant the display of a pup-under, in post-it color (yellow background, nice dark bold font) of the URL.  Probably does not take much for somebody familiar with the source code to implement.  But it is your software, your call.  Just don't be surprised if I decide to use an alternative email client.

>  security by obscurity is no security

You have gone down an unnecessary argument.  My request has nothing to do with security by obscurity.  If anything, it is the opposite:  security by clarity, making sure that the information that is relevant to keep the user secure is displayed in a way that catches the user's attention, instead of being placed in an obscure, peripheral grey on gray status line.

> I'd add to it: users do mistakes, regardless how much the software tries to avoid it.

This is no excuse for not trying to make the software less mistake-prone.  But again, it is your software, your call.  If you are happy with the way it is, let it be.  At some point, some other software will do it better than Evolution.  This is... natural evolution (pun intended).

events.target_title: [Prefer Plain] Generate plain text from text/html, if not available

note.body:
> Sure you can guess random stuff, for example missing character encoding information. The guess can sometimes be correct, like your test-drive of Mozilla Thunderbird. It can also sometimes be wrong. Your mileage may vary.

Guess, or estimate (as in: use the user's locale) or have a settings.  My experience with Mozilla Thunderbird in about ten years is that its estimates (or guesses) are >99% correct.  Might be because of the limited selection of scripts/languages in which I receive regular message, though if I trust my recognition of foreign scripts that arrive with spam messages, it seems to be estimating right also on those.

> Feel free to run usability tests if you have such resources handy. We do not have.

The next-best thing that you do have is the possibility to accept user-feedback.  When I was doing development, many many years ago, user-feedback, and in particular feedback from outsiders that had not settled with the quirks of the existing UI, was the most valuable way to progress.  The obstacle was first cultural: it is easy for an outsider to break etiquette and offend insiders / do something wrong.  And it is easy for insiders to just brush off the outsiders.  I designed securities trading platforms for professional traders and for individual investors from the general public.  What was obvious to the trader was everything but to the  general public.  But as I said, it is your software, not mine, so I do not insist.  Feel free to ignore my feedback.

> With all due respect, whatever desktop theme you use, it's not Evolution's problem.

You are right about the theme.  The placement of the information on the UI layout is not a theme issue AFAIK and this piece of important information is placed by the Evolution UI in a peripheral area.  FYI, I did not change the color scheme.  I use Xubuntu 18.04LTS out of the box.  I generally do not customize themes.  The only exception is that I change the font and the magnification factor to fit the screen size/resolution and my ageing eyes.

Improve documentation

note.body: A more systematic approach is that we make sure each function appears in at least one example, and in the doc for each function, a link to at one example is provided. That way less examples are required and the documentation will work great.

events.target_title: When Creating New f2fs Partition Start & Finish Can default To Odd (i.e. Not Even) MiB Boundaries
When Creating New f2fs Partition Start & Finish Can default To Odd (i.e. Not Even) MiB Boundaries

note.body:
Thanks for your response Mike. I decided to buy a new flash drive in case that was where the fault lay. These results are from my new " Samsung MUF-64BE4/EU 64 GB Bar Plus Titan USB Flash Drive." I used Windows 7 to convert the format from exFAT to ntfs.

I then logged into Linux. Some version info for you:
Linux Mint 18.3 (fully updated)
Kernal 4.15.0-36-generic
gparted 0.25.0-1
f2fs-tools 1.6.1-1

Using gparted I deleted the ntfs partition, rebuilt the partition table in msdos format and then added a new f2fs partition for the whole drive using the default gparted settings. As before, I got an error message. Please see attached screen prints as requested.

Then I deleted the f2fs partition and created a new f2fs partition but this time I moved the start point to 2MiB and reduced the size by 1 MiB to make it even. Unfortunately this time this strategy did not clear the error. The drive is mountable but I was unable to change the drive permissions to make the drive  writeable by the user ("Permissions could not be determined" in properties).![Screenshot_from_2018-10-11_14-14-56](/uploads/715eabd4af95055c8ea21522627d8515/Screenshot_from_2018-10-11_14-14-56.png)

events.target_title: When Creating New f2fs Partition Start & Finish Can default To Odd (i.e. Not Even) MiB Boundaries

note.body:
Thank you for your illuminating reply Mike. For me, resizing is just one of the many useful capabilities of gparted that I regularly use so I could live without that. (Greyed out say.) The other problem you mention of not being able to write to an unmounted file system is I believe well made. I assume that the fact that I cannot use the created partition after an automatic system mount (usb remove/insert) is likely a question for f2fs-tools. 

If f2fs is a known systematic failure in gparted I do wonder why it is provided as an option at all or not greyed out, say. Perhaps I am misunderstanding how these things are done.

I am happy that the issue be closed with these comments but i would be interested in your thoughts if you have the time. Many thanks, Clive.

events.target_title: Transformation tools leave fuzzy white or transparent space at edges
Transformation tools leave fuzzy white or transparent space at edges

note.body:
Having seen no uptake on this, and suspecting that the detail I provided may seem a bit overwhelming, I'm offering a simplified series of steps and some additional insights into this bug.

To see this bug;
1) Using any jpg, select a rectangular area within it
2) Click on the Unified Transform tool and then click in the selection
3) Using one of the side handles, either stretch or shrink the selection by any amount (everything appears correct to this point)
4) Anchor the resulting floating layer
5) If an unwanted row of pixels is not evident on both the 'base' and the 'stretched', or 'handle', side of the selection, zoom in to 100% or more.

Here are some curious things: 
- The colour of these unwanted rows of pixels depends on the background colour set in the Toolbox!
- It doesn't matter how little you stretch or shrink the selection, it produces the unwanted edges, at least one pixel wide.
- The unwanted edges are actually transparent, as can be seen if the floating result is converted to a new layer.
All this suggests to me that the problem lies in the handling of the 'abyss', but I don't have the programming skills to investigate further.  So, I'm hoping someone soon will, as this is a real show-stopper for the work I'm doing.

The screen capture below shows the Unified Transform tool being used to shrink a selection by the smallest possible amount (at 400%). Note that the preview appears as one would expect.
![Capture5](/uploads/f51cc0dbdf7af55c29a710e8d3098d1a/Capture5.JPG)

After hitting the Transform button (with the Toolbox Background colour set to a Royal Blue), the unwanted fringes are already evident, even before anchoring the selection to get rid of the marching ants.
![Capture6](/uploads/e215348ed70b3881e505272b43f8e5bb/Capture6.JPG)

events.target_title: Transformation tools leave fuzzy white or transparent space at edges

note.body:
Having done still further investigation, I now see that the Interpolation method DOES matter! Each of the methods, except 'None', has the effect described above. However, when, None is chosen, things appear as expected, i.e., there is no fringe effect!  Interestingly, 'None' also seems to be best in terms of preserving image quality (sharpness), so it begs the question: Why are these alternative methods even provided?  And why would 'Linear' be the default?
Anyway, I'm much happier now, having found a workable method.  It looks looks like we need a Help entry for the Unified Transform tool; but first it would be good to know what to make of all the unusable options that were added to 2.10.

events.target_title: Color picker should show current pixel color in a tooltip

note.body: I, too, would welcome tooltip functionality for the Color Picker. A simple display of RGB percentages or values would be all that's required.  This would make it much easier to assess subtle color gradients, and to compare different parts of the image.  Further, it would be great to be able to make direct comparisons between a reference point (the result of a left click and as displayed in the dialog box) and the values at the roving tooltip.  Currently, to do this you have to rely on short-term memory regarding both the location and values of the previous click.  So, in addition to the tooltip, I would like to see a temporary marker (a blinking(?) circle representing the area sampled) at the location of the most recent mouse click.  It would disappear when the tool or the dialogue is dismissed.

events.target_title: Evince simply quits without crashing nor showing anything
Vala autocompletion doesn't work in Builder 3.30 (flatpak version)
Compiled code crashes trying to clone an array with length of -1
Using move() on an array containing reference counted objects causes leaks
Using move() on an array containing reference counted objects causes leaks

note.body:
While the other bug says "it is documented" - I was unable to find that documentation.

Also this behavior works against the rest of vala's memory model and automatic memory management.
It is easy to forget to zero array elements you overwrite as a programmer while valac knows exactly which elements are overwritten (it can even use the same method used for freeing the array).

note.body:
FOUND IT! (I guess)

It is a DConf setting

    org.gnome.Lollypop allow-per-track-cover

the default is `false`. But when it i set on `true`, the issue occurs.

It is a shame, I love to put on recopilations the album art of each track in the ID3 tags, so I can keep track of where they come.

events.target_title: Perpetual move cursor
Perpetual move cursor

note.body:
It's an interesting idea but my feature request is not that at all.

It's actually a cursor that can pan in any direction indefinitely. 

When a cursor hits the edge of the "viewport" while panning it will show up on the translated opposite edge of the viewport and keep panning. So you can pan as long as you can move your mouse on your desk, the cursor doesn't care.

Basically it won't stop panning when the cursor hits the edge of the screen as it does currently and you won't need to stop panning, move the cursor back and begin panning again as it works currently.

Idk if you noticed there is a YouTube video in the bug report that shows exactly the behaviour of the cursor:
[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WnBzOkb0Gb0&feature=youtu.be](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WnBzOkb0Gb0&feature=youtu.be)

events.target_title: Perpetual move cursor

note.body:
I don't think this couldn't work for graphics tablets, most people use Blender with graphics tablets and praise this feature.

It's not that you need an infinite desk but that you can do infinite movement on a finite desk space.
So to illustrate how that works please watch this short video.
[https://youtu.be/6jx8hcnZaOg](https://youtu.be/6jx8hcnZaOg)

Note, with this feature you can still use your mouse and cursor in the traditional way, by moving your cursor back and forth if you want.

events.target_title: Perpetual move cursor

note.body:
Yes Yes, that would be fine for my use case since I'm yet to purchase a graphics tablet.

I'm not so technical but I think the infinite panning is always enabled in Blender, it's just that the movement of the cursor and pen are 1:1 so you cannot pass the viewport? I'm just guessing tho here tho.

If you know exactly what to ask, maybe you could post a question to the https://devtalk.blender.org/ ? I'd be really interested to know if and how that works with graphic tablet too.

But for the mouse and keyboard, this is really a killer feature and I miss it every day in Gimp and Inkscape.

events.target_title: Perpetual move cursor

note.body:
I've created a topic there so I think more info should be coming soon :)
[https://devtalk.blender.org/t/blenders-perpetual-panning-cursor/5105](https://devtalk.blender.org/t/blenders-perpetual-panning-cursor/5105)

events.target_title: Perpetual move cursor

note.body:
the user brecht said:
"It’s called Continuous Grab in the preferences and you can look for GHOST_kGrabWrap in the code."
and
"For graphics tablets this doesn’t really do anything by the way, if you reach the edge of the tablet you can’t go any further. For a mouse there is no physical edge, so it’s maybe more frustrating if the application appears to artificially limit things."

So I think I was right about the tablet, it can't go past the viewport. Still needs test conformation tho.

events.target_title: Perpetual move cursor

note.body:
I'm trying to say that the feature it's turned off when using tablet but just that the tablet isn't making use of it and can't make use of it on the tablet side but the feature exists in the program itself. But I'm just guessing so I will agree with you on this since you know what you are talking about much more than I :D

as far as panning goes, here are some steps:

1. launch Blender
2. pan with SHIFT+Middle mouse button
3. observe how real panning works, not the rotation that I gave in the previous example.

I think it's great for panning.

There is also zoom in and zoom out with CTRL+Middle mouse button and raging the mouse up or down.
But every feature is better imo with perpetually moving cursor.

events.target_title: Touchpad and Trackpoint locked together in Wayland session

note.body:
Well, this all seems to be a kernel bug after all.
You should be using hid-alps.ko, and AFAICT, hid-alps doesn't handle the case where the touchpad node is not opened while listening to the trackstick node.

The following patch should help (untested though): [0001-HID-alps-allow-incoming-reports-when-only-the-tracks.patch](/uploads/49ec8d4487221ccc87d6dfd89d2228e8/0001-HID-alps-allow-incoming-reports-when-only-the-tracks.patch)

Can you also provide some hid-recorder of your touchpad/trackstick (package hid-replay in fedora)?
With the hid-recorder logs I should be able to ensure the patch is correct and also add it to the HID test suite I am building to prevent further regressions.

events.target_title: Touchpad and Trackpoint locked together in Wayland session

note.body:
Thanks for the logs. Unfortunately, I am able to somehow test the patch but can't be definitive given that mutter is not that happy with more than one touchpad/trackstick.

Is there any chances you can recompile hid-alps.ko with the patch attached? If not, I should be able to launch a koji build, but that will need to wait tomorrow.

> Is the patch in for 4.19 or 4.20?

in neither of those, I just wrote it this morning :)

If tests show that it fixes the issue, it shouldn't be an issue to have it in 4.20 (hopefully). But it's too late for 4.19 unless we request a stable backport.

Okay I looked a bit around and what was making me think is, that you don't inhibit lid-switch by default, but only under some circumstances, which I never really got (My impression was that suspend shouldn't kick in, when connected to an external monitor? For me it always suspend unless I turn that off in gnome-tweaks).
So if lid-switch-handle is not inhibited by default systemd suspends the system, but isn't gsd also going to run through its code and eventually tries to suspend the system? 
Could be that I didn't got how the code paths were but this was my impression. 
If I'm wrong I would love get response were I was misleaded.
And If not than I'm glad to help!

note.body:
So what about just drawing them as straight lines?  that seems like it would be better than not drawing them at all, no?

from what i can see from the screenshots, it's just the pen tool that's having this problem, and it is not being rendered at all.

If poppler/evince ends up rendering it according to spec, and it doesn't look the way the Onyx reader wants it to look, then we can try to get the Onyx reader to fix their generation.  But as long as poppler-based viewers don't render it at all and report `unimplemented annotation`, the Onyx folks are likely to shrug and carry on doing what they're doing.

upgrading to gmime 3 would be really useful for me.  i've been helping to maintain the gmime packages in debian, and they don't see the same level of support (either from upstream, or from me as a downstream maintainer) as gmime 3 does.  please consider bumping up the priority on this work.

I wasn't able to trivially rebase `wip/gmime3` against the current `master`, unfortunately, it looks like it's diverged quite a bit.

i'm hoping to drop gmime 2.6 from debian before the next release ("bullseye") and geary and balsa are the only two [blockers for that transition](https://bugs.debian.org/867345).  I consider them both pretty important!

If I didn't already know I could configure gnome-terminal via gsettings (which I did not, I didn't know anything about gsettings), how would I know to look for those settings?


Here is a dump of all the help options + the man page in Debian. I can't find any reference to gsettings:

```

  --gtk-no-debug=FLAGS            GTK+ debugging flags to unset

Options to open new windows or terminal tabs; more than one of these may be specified:
  --window                        Open a new window containing a tab with the default profile
  --tab                           Open a new tab in the last-opened window with the default profile

Window options; if used before the first --window or --tab argument, sets the default for all windows:

  --maximize                      Maximize the window
  --full-screen                   Full-screen the window

  --g-fatal-warnings              Make all warnings fatal

  --gtk-no-debug=FLAGS            GTK+ debugging flags to unset

Usage:
  gnome-terminal [OPTION…] [-- COMMAND …]

Options to open new windows or terminal tabs; more than one of these may be specified:
  --window                        Open a new window containing a tab with the default profile
  --tab                           Open a new tab in the last-opened window with the default profile

Usage:
  gnome-terminal [OPTION…] [-- COMMAND …]

Window options; if used before the first --window or --tab argument, sets the default for all windows:
  --show-menubar                  Turn on the menubar
  --hide-menubar                  Turn off the menubar
  --maximize                      Maximize the window
  --full-screen                   Full-screen the window
  --geometry=GEOMETRY             Set the window size; for example: 80x24, or 80x24+200+200 (COLSxROWS+X+Y)
  --role=ROLE                     Set the window role
  --active                        Set the last specified tab as the active one in its window

Usage:
  gnome-terminal [OPTION…] [-- COMMAND …]

Terminal options; if used before the first --window or --tab argument, sets the default for all terminals:
  -e, --command                   Execute the argument to this option inside the terminal
  --profile=PROFILE-NAME          Use the given profile instead of the default profile
  --working-directory=DIRNAME     Set the working directory
  --zoom=ZOOM                     Set the terminal’s zoom factor (1.0 = normal size)

gnome-terminal(1)                                        General Commands Manual                                        gnome-terminal(1)

NAME
       gnome-terminal — is a terminal emulation application.

SYNOPSIS
       gnome-terminal  [-e,  --command=STRING]   [-x,  --execute ]  [--window-with-profile=PROFILENAME]  [--tab-with-profile=PROFILENAME]
       [--window-with-profile-internal-id=PROFILEID]    [--tab-with-profile-internal-id=PROFILEID]     [--role=ROLE]     [--show-menubar]
       [--hide-menubar]  [--geometry=GEOMETRY]  [--working-directory=DIRNAME]  [-?, --help]

DESCRIPTION
       GNOME Terminal is a terminal emulation application that you can use to perform the following actions:

       Access a UNIX shell in the GNOME environment.

       A shell is a program that interprets and executes the commands that you type at a command line prompt. When you start GNOME Termi‐
       nal, the application starts the default shell that is specified in your system account. You can switch to a different shell at any
       time.

       Run any application that is designed to run on VT102, VT220, and xterm terminals.

       GNOME  Terminal emulates the xterm program developed by the X Consortium. In turn, the xterm program emulates the DEC VT102 termi‐
       nal and also supports the DEC VT220 escape sequences. An escape sequence is a series of characters that starts with the Esc  char‐
       acter.

       GNOME  Terminal  accepts  all of the escape sequences that the VT102 and VT220 terminals use for functions such as positioning the
       cursor and clearing the screen.

OPTIONS
       -e, --command=STRING
                 Execute the argument to this option inside the terminal.

       -x, --execute
                 Execute the remainder of the command line inside the terminal.

       --window-with-profile=PROFILENAME
                 Open a new window containing a tab with the given profile.  More than one of these options can be provided.

       --tab-with-profile=PROFILENAME
                 Open a tab in the window with the given profile. More than one of these options can be provided, to open several tabs .

       --window-with-profile-internal-id=PROFILEID
                 Open a new window containing a tab with the given profile ID. Used internally to save sessions.

       --tab-with-profile-internal-id=PROFILEID
                 Open a tab in the window with the given profile ID.  Used internally to save sessions.

       --role=ROLE
                 Set the role for the last-specified window; applies to only one window; can be specified once for each window you create
                 from the command line.

       --show-menubar
                 Turn  on  the  menu bar for the last-specified window; applies to only one window; can be specified once for each window
                 you create from the command line.

       --hide-menubar
                 Turn off the menu bar for the last-specified window; applies to only one window; can be specified once for  each  window
                 you create from the command line.

       --geometry=GEOMETRY
                 X geometry specification (see "X" man page), can be specified once per window to be opened.

       --working-directory=DIRNAME
                 Set the terminal's working directory to DIRNAME.

       -?, --help
                 Show help message.

AUTHOR
       This  manual  page  was written by Christian Marillat marillat@debian.org for the Debian GNU/Linux system (but may be used by oth‐
       ers).

                                                                                                                        gnome-terminal(1)
```

So I did a web search. I found this page:

https://help.gnome.org/users/gnome-terminal/stable/

But I didn't see any reference to gsettings even in the "Advanced Settings" section.

Digging deeper, I found this FAQ page, which finally has a section: "How can I change a profile setting from the command line?" and some examples:

https://wiki.gnome.org/Apps/Terminal/FAQ

But even given this example, when trying to adapt it to make a profile setting change, I ran into this problem:

https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-terminal/issues/40

and I discovered there are apparently profile and global settings, a distinction I couldn't make out from the example, which only mentions profile settings.

Given the lack of documentation around it, is gsettings even an officially supported/approved way of configuring gnome-terminal?

events.target_title: Enhance CLI documentation

note.body:
I also found org.gnome.Terminal.SettingsList, but are these supposed to return something empty?

```
$ gsettings get org.gnome.Terminal.SettingsList:/ list
@as []
$ gsettings get org.gnome.Terminal.SettingsList:/ default
''
```

But I can confirm tab completion works to at least discover the keys:

```
$ gsettings get org.gnome.Terminal.Legacy.Settings <tab>
confirm-close              menu-accelerator-enabled   schema-version             tab-policy                 
default-show-menubar       mnemonics-enabled          shell-integration-enabled  tab-position               
encodings                  new-terminal-mode          shortcuts-enabled          theme-variant              
```

Even if I knew what are the keys, how am I supposed to know what are possible values for e.g. `tab-policy`?

events.target_title: Xorg sessions have higher output lag than Wayland sessions [performance]

note.body: @vanvugt This isn't true. Xorg is using a hardware cursor, while Wayland is using a software cursor. A hardware cursor is drawn during scanout by the graphics card, while a software cursor is drawn during composition. So what you're seeing is the mouse cursor lagging one frame behind on Wayland, which means it updates position at the same time the window moves and stays in sync.

events.target_title: Xorg sessions have higher output lag than Wayland sessions [performance]

note.body:
I still think it's the mouse cursor lagging one frame behind on Wayland. The fact that it's a hardware cursor is a revelation to me, but I can definitely tell the cursor isn't quite as responsive in Wayland, even though the actual windows move around with the same latency as Xorg. The input updates for the cursor in Mutter must not be granular enough to hit scan-out deadlines that the X server could. 

Increasing the update frequency so the mouse cursor has less lag would increase the cursor<->window discrepancy so that Wayland behaves like Xorg, not the other way around. It's likely not possible to decrease the compositor lag much further without removing vsync, or at least Windows/OS X haven't figured it out yet, either.

events.target_title: Xorg sessions have higher output lag than Wayland sessions [performance]

note.body:
Actually, trying your patch yields a new gap between the cursor and window for me on Wayland. The mouse becomes more responsive by a frame, but the windows don't, producing a gap where there wasn't before. No noticeable difference on X11. 

This is a major net positive, though. I definitely like the mouse reacting as quickly as possible, even if it's decoupled.

events.target_title: XDG-Decoration support

note.body:
>  As mentioned before, then decorations are the least of their problem. Unless of course you are referring to the case where the developer is perfectly happy with 99% of the window looking different, but really really want the remaining percent to be consistent with other applications. Sure, that's a use case, but it's also kinda silly.

What they want is for their dumb frame-buffer application to be encapsulated by a window. Think a video stream or a classic arcade game. There's nothing that would clash with a window border created by the current desktop environment. 

> I think that most distributions will eventually patch mutter to support ssd and then gnome will have no choice :P

It's not that easy. As the developers have mentioned, Wayland compositors are not window managers. Wayland is abstract from these concepts and mostly deals with surfaces. It doesn't look like there's code in Mutter to use simply to draw decorations with, and if you knew the disjointed way Metacity drew decorations on X11, you probably wouldn't want to use that. Plus you have to worry about how to handle the decoration surface with respect to the top-level surface and when and how to draw it, and how to handle events from it. There's no existing code to get you started.

events.target_title: XDG-Decoration support

note.body:
>The problem is that even if GLFW/SDL/Allegro/etc. would be willing to use GTK (as the mentioned 'toolkit library') for proper client-side decorations, they can't really do it. While GdkGLContext may be usable by these libraries, there's no equivalent Vulkan context interface in GTK3, and the one in GTK4 is pretty limited currently, as it's just a read-only interface for the already created instance and device.
>
>Given the above, and the fact that these low-level libraries obviously don't want to depend on GTK (as they're operating basically on the same level), the "use a toolkit library" path is simply impossible to take in this case.

That's part of the problem here. Mutter/Wayland doesn't use GTK+. You can't let GTK+ handle the surface because using its event loop for a compositor would be a nightmare. Plus, the developers are now trying to stay reasonably separated from toolkits. That's why they forked clutter and are even thinking of getting rid of that. 

Essentially, what we're asking them is "Add new code to Mutter to draw decorations and handle them. Add a decorator that uses GTK+ and scrapes the output." It's not like you can just "let" Mutter do it. It's a substantial amount of work, and goes against the design that says Mutter shouldn't be aware of things like that. Mutter was designed this way partly because the X11 decoration handling and reparenting was such a messy affair. 

I would like for these framebuffer libraries to be able to have consistent window decorations, too, but try to understand the barriers that make it so difficult.

events.target_title: clutter-stage-cogl: Don't skip past the next frame [performance]

note.body:
I'm finding this patch causes a lot of client frame-skipping in intervals of 3 seconds on/3 seconds off. !281 alone is perfectly fine.

```c
-  while (stage_cogl->update_time < now)
-    stage_cogl->update_time += refresh_interval;
+  if (stage_cogl->update_time < now)
+    stage_cogl->update_time = now
```
From experience, this strikes me as a really bad idea. It messes with frame-pacing and is probably causing irregularity in the compositor/client rhythm. 

If !281 interacts with !152 and needs !282, I'd rather !152 and !282 both go away. You could try a META_SYNC_DELAY of 1 instead of 2. I think a little delay is necessary because otherwise clients will be in a vblank race with the compositor.

events.target_title: clutter-stage-cogl: Don't skip past the next frame [performance]

note.body:
Xorg/RX 580. 1 monitor. 59.997hz.

Chromium: vsynctester.com

Without !282: Consistently smooth once things have settled.

With !282: Periods where it's janky (seemingly 30fps) for ~3 seconds, then smooth for ~3 seconds. 

Basically, during the janky periods, a race is happening where Chromium is getting 2 frames in for 1 compositor frame, then the next compositor frame it gets 0 and so on. 

I don't think you should try and take the clients' data right after vsync, because it's up in the air whether the compositor or the client, both waiting to swap, got to go first. It's not possible to check if all the clients have finished, so I believe that's the reason why the META_SYNC_DELAY was added.

I could be wrong, though. I'm just guessing based on some experience.

events.target_title: clutter-stage-cogl: Don't skip past the next frame [performance]

note.body:
It'll actually take 5.55 seconds to generate an extra frame at 59.997hz, so that doesn't quite match up, but it might be related, so if you want to chase that path, go ahead. 
*edited* Playing with the patches now, it's definitely not as predictable/consistent as I thought, so definitely ignore that idea.

See https://bugzilla.gnome.org/show_bug.cgi?id=692901 for the original clutter sync delay commit and Owen's reasoning linked a couple posts down. It's there for exactly the reason I suggested.
