events.target_title: clutter-stage-cogl: Don't skip past the next frame [performance]

note.body: And it appears *increasing* META_SYNC_DELAY will *decrease* latency in the case clients aren't synced to vblank, because it pushes the time we read clients' framebuffers closer to the time we present them, meaning their framebuffers can be more-up-to-date. Back then, it was known that it would increase latency by FRAME_INTERVAL - META_SYNC_DELAY, but was justified because it would reduce jitter.

events.target_title: clutter-stage-cogl: Don't skip past the next frame [performance]

note.body:
I don't mean to be annoying, but I thought this might be helpful.

Apple's Aqua compositor reports false vsync timestamps to composited CGL clients halfway between the real vsync to avoid swapbuffers contention. I realized the sync delay is very similar, but with the extra complexity because it can't control clients' GL libraries and has to offset it in the compositor. I'm now definitely of the opinion that the META_SYNC_DELAY is a good thing, and shouldn't be removed.

events.target_title: Bug places events one day back upon editing.

note.body:
Since I am also affected of this really nasty and annoying issue on at least two machines (Arch Linux: installed gnome-calendar from distribution repo; Ubuntu 18.04: installed from flathub), I wanted to see if I can gather some more information.

So far, I did some "print debugging" to try pinning down where the date suddenly changes a day back. This showed that the day change has happened after the call to `g_date_to_timezone ()` in [line 319 of gcal-edit-dialog.c](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-calendar/blob/master/src/gcal-edit-dialog.c#L319).

I added these lines around the call:

```diff
diff --git a/src/gcal-edit-dialog.c b/src/gcal-edit-dialog.c
index 051816fd..48e6e606 100644
--- a/src/gcal-edit-dialog.c
+++ b/src/gcal-edit-dialog.c
@@ -316,7 +316,10 @@ return_datetime_for_widgets (GcalEditDialog   *self,
                                             all_day ? 0 : g_date_time_get_minute (time),
                                             0);
 
+  g_message("Day in local timezone: %i", g_date_time_get_day_of_month (date_in_local_tz));
   date_in_best_tz = g_date_time_to_timezone (date_in_local_tz, timezone);
+  g_message("\"Best\" time zone is: %s", g_time_zone_get_identifier(timezone));
+  g_message("Day in \"best\" timezone: %i", g_date_time_get_day_of_month (date_in_best_tz));
 
   retval = g_date_time_new (timezone,
                             g_date_time_get_year (date_in_best_tz),

```

Which lead to these messages (included the standard DEBUG messages that originate in `on_action_button_clicked_cb ()`, [line 789–90](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-calendar/blob/master/src/gcal-edit-dialog.c#L789)):

```
18:04:13.0253            GcalEditDialog:  MESSAGE: Day in local timezone: 20
18:04:13.0253            GcalEditDialog:  MESSAGE: "Best" time zone is: UTC
18:04:13.0253            GcalEditDialog:  MESSAGE: Day in "best" timezone: 19
18:04:13.0253            GcalEditDialog:    DEBUG: New start date: 01/19/2019 12:00:00 AM +0000
18:04:13.0253            GcalEditDialog:    DEBUG: New end date: 01/19/2019 12:00:00 AM +0000
```

Perhaps someone knowing the codebase (I don't) is able to fix this? If you need more information, I'm willing to help providing them.

Note: The "print debugging" was done on master (cloned using the gnome-builder welcome screen), but as I've stated in the beginning, this issue is in released versions, at least in the official Arch Linux repos and on flathub.

events.target_title: Bug places events one day back upon editing.

note.body:
Should have added this before, this is my local timezone information (from the Arch Linux machine):

```
               Local time: So 2019-01-20 18:20:20 CET
           Universal time: So 2019-01-20 17:20:20 UTC
                 RTC time: So 2019-01-20 17:20:20
                Time zone: Europe/Berlin (CET, +0100)
System clock synchronized: yes
              NTP service: active
          RTC in local TZ: no
```

events.target_title: Bug places events one day back upon editing.

note.body:
Since the bug only appears when creating all-day events using the full event dialog (i.e. not the quick-add popover!), I do think by now that the bug is caused by creating `date_in_local_tz` with time 00:00:00 in case of an allday event ([line 312](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-calendar/blob/master/src/gcal-edit-dialog.c#L312)). This date (for example: 20 January 2019, 00:00:00 CET +0100 in my case) is then being converted to UTC in line 319 (which translates our example to 19 January 2019, 23:00:00 UTC, i.e. one day to early).

A quick test showed that the following patch creates all-day events on the correct date, at least for my timezone:

```patch
diff --git a/src/gcal-edit-dialog.c b/src/gcal-edit-dialog.c
index 051816fd..2c2948f0 100644
--- a/src/gcal-edit-dialog.c
+++ b/src/gcal-edit-dialog.c
@@ -312,7 +312,7 @@ return_datetime_for_widgets (GcalEditDialog   *self,
   date_in_local_tz = g_date_time_new_local (g_date_time_get_year (date),
                                             g_date_time_get_month (date),
                                             g_date_time_get_day_of_month (date),
-                                            all_day ? 0 : g_date_time_get_hour (time),
+                                            all_day ? 12 : g_date_time_get_hour (time),
                                             all_day ? 0 : g_date_time_get_minute (time),
                                             0);
 
```

I don't think that this is already a correct fix since Wikipedia tells me that there are timezones having a +1300 or +1400 (DST) difference to UTC. But using `13` or `14` as value for the hour should cause issues in all far-western time zones. So, I think I have to leave finding a fix to the timezone experts here.

Yet, as far as I understand now, creating all-day events using the edit dialog *should currently be buggy in all timezones with a positive offset from UTC,* so I think a proper fix would help *a lot* of people.

I have just tested again:

Are there any reasons/road blocks why not to merge !61 at least during the current development cycle and have it included also with the next 3.32.x bug fix release?

It also seems to me that #385 is a duplicate of this issue.

events.target_title: gnome-boxes breaks Windows 10 guest by changing scsi controller to lsilogic from virtio-scsi on startup of gnome-boxes
gnome-boxes breaks Windows 10 guest by changing scsi controller to lsilogic from virtio-scsi on startup of gnome-boxes

note.body:
I have been digging a little deeper and apparently, only VMs originally created with Boxes are affected. To be precise, adding this to the `<metadata>`-section of the xml file makes Boxes replace `virtio-scsi` with `lsilogic` (happens with Windows 7 as well):

```
<boxes:gnome-boxes xmlns:boxes="https://wiki.gnome.org/Apps/Boxes">
  <os-state>installed</os-state>
  <os-id>http://microsoft.com/win/10</os-id>
  <media-id>http://microsoft.com/win/10:7</media-id>
  <media>/path/to/windows.iso</media>
</boxes:gnome-boxes>
```

removing these lines solves the issue.
Given that `lsilogic` isn't a suitable driver on modern versions of Windows or even readily available, I'd consider this as a bug, even though Boxes itself doesn't allow users to change the disk driver to `virtio-scsi`.

The log is quite long and doesn't seem to include anything interesting, I'm including it if you still need more info.

[vm.xml](/uploads/1d6d56cd1d531f3ee0d222e237b76228/vm.xml)

Use gsettings rather than gconf
elogind support

note.body:
It is great that you are trying to ship a portable image that can be installed on any system (that uses systemd >239 and flatpak). But also consider that there are alternative distribution mechanisms for you software. Distros like gentoo and void will be providing their own init configuration, so the need for portable services is not relevant. They would benefit from not having to maintain the elogind sd-bus patch in parallel with each other.

As an application developer, nobody expects you to remove the hard depends on portable services for your flatpak, or to test that your application works with libelogind. I believe the scope of this patch is well understood by all parties: to avoid a dependency on **libsystemd** by using the alternative **libelogind**, which is completely API compatible. Any issues resulting from the use of libelogind would first be considered a bug in elogind, and you would not be bothered to maintain the functionality.

events.target_title: Print options should be saved per printer across sessions

note.body:
I totally agree. I have 2 printers:
* `Printer_A4` for printing normal A4 letters (printer settings configured to be paper size of A4)
* `Printer_A5` for printing address labels (printer settings configured to be A5)

Now it seems that evince "overwrites" the default printer settings by its own settings.

I print with the `Printer_A4` and then the Evince setting is:
```console
$ cat ~/.config/evince/print-settings
[Print Settings]
...
printer=Printer_A4
...

[Page Setup]
PPDName=A4
DisplayName=A4
Width=210
Height=297
MarginTop=2.9600045098198784
MarginBottom=2.9600001361634996
MarginLeft=2.9600001361634996
MarginRight=2.9600045098198784
Orientation=portrait
```

So page is set to A4.

Next time I want to print a A5 label with the other printer, then I have to remember to re-set this to A5 which will then be also stored:

```console

$ cat ~/.config/evince/print-settings
[Print Settings]
...
printer=Printer_A5
...

[Page Setup]
PPDName=A5
DisplayName=A5
Width=148
Height=210
MarginTop=2.9999891493055553
MarginBottom=2.9999999152289494
MarginLeft=2.9999999152289494
MarginRight=2.9999999152289494
Orientation=portrait
```

Evince should just use the printer settings that operate on a "per printer" basis. Evince shoulw not have its own printer settings.

I have found that users try to workaround this by not allowing Evince to write (save) to its settings file. But I am not sure if this has (future) side effect...

https://askubuntu.com/questions/679705/evince-pdf-viewer-how-to-automatically-reset-printer-settings-on-exit

events.target_title: Print options should be saved per printer across sessions

note.body:
FWIW, there are other user having the same problem:

* https://askubuntu.com/questions/528479/how-do-you-make-printing-use-default-settings-every-time-you-print
* https://askubuntu.com/questions/1012693/is-there-a-way-to-disable-paper-size-remembering-in-default-print-dialogue

And this is just what a quick search on askubuntu shows ;)

I think it's worth looking how other OSs or applications handle this. I think it is very rare that an application does not use the default printer settings.

Tracker no longer returns files with hyphens in the filename, when the search string contains a hyphen

note.body:
I have a slightly different observation that should be connected to this issue:

If a filename contains a hyphen and is copied and renamed (without a hyphen in its name), only then the content of the renamed file is indexed and therefore can be searched. To reproduce, copy and rename [this](https://mega.nz/#!bo5g3K4S!NSZjXZiHhBCJYfXxoPH2CAly6HdNsXaLIFgtM4ZHUyE) pdf into something generic, let tracker index both files and search for f.i. `Oxenfahrt` and you'll see that tracker will find the word in the renamed pdf, but not the original one.

Can somebody confirm this?

Observed on Ubuntu 18.10 with tracker 2.0.3-3.

note.body:
Meaning is: if you decide to use mformat then use at least version 4.0.19 (which fixed some bugs). Sorry for confusion. I do not compare mformat vs mkdosfs, both are good.

This change just allow to format FAT filesystems without need to install dosfstools. mformat is part of mtools and mtools is already required for changing volume label (via mlabel). So this change does not add any new dependency.
